# Shortcodes

The `academicCVTemplate` uses Quarto shortcodes to insert dynamic content into your CV. This allows you to place your data exactly where you want it in the document without writing any complex R code.

## `{{< cv-section >}}`

The `cv-section` shortcode is the workhorse of your CV. It fetches data from a specific sheet in your Google Spreadsheet (or cached data) and renders it using a Typst function.

### Basic Usage

```markdown
{{< cv-section sheet="working" func="resume-entry" >}}
```

### Arguments

| Argument | Description | Default | Example |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| `sheet` | **Required.** The `shortname` of the sheet to load data from (as defined in `google-document` config). | - | `sheet="working"` |
| `func` | **Required.** The name of the Typst function to use for rendering each entry. | - | `func="resume-entry"` |
| `exclude_cols` | A comma-separated list of columns to exclude from the data passed to the Typst function. Supports "tidy select" features. | `""` | `exclude_cols="id, note*"` |
| `combine_cols` | A comma-separated list of columns to combine into a single text block (e.g., bullet points). Supports "tidy select". | `""` | `combine_cols="starts_with('detail')"` |
| `combine_as` | The name of the new column where the combined text will be stored. | `"details"` | `combine_as="description"` |
| `combine_sep` | The separator used between combined items. | `" "` | `combine_sep="\ \ "` (Typst line break) |
| `combine_prefix` | A prefix string added before each item in the combined list (e.g., a bullet point). | `""` | `combine_prefix="Â· "` |
| `column_order` | Explicitly reorder columns or move specific columns to indices. | `""` | `column_order="title=1, date=2"` |
| `na_action` | How to handle empty/NA values. Options: `"omit"` (remove key), `"keep"` (pass as `none`), `"string"` (pass as `"NA"`). | `"omit"` | `na_action="keep"` |

### "Tidy Select" Features

For `exclude_cols` and `combine_cols`, you can use powerful selection helpers:

*   **Exact Name:** `title` selects the column named "title".
*   **Range:** `start:end` selects all columns from "start" to "end" (inclusive).
*   **`starts_with("...")`**: Selects columns starting with the prefix.
*   **`ends_with("...")`**: Selects columns ending with the suffix.
*   **`contains("...")`**: Selects columns containing the string.
*   **`matches("...")`**: Selects columns matching a Lua pattern.

**Example:**
```markdown
{{< cv-section
    sheet="working"
    func="resume-entry"
    combine_cols="starts_with('detail')"
    combine_prefix="-- "
    combine_sep="\n"
>}}
```

## `{{< publication-list >}}`

The `publication-list` shortcode automatically generates a formatted list of publications from a bibliography file (BibTeX, CSL-JSON, RIS, etc.).

### Basic Usage

```markdown
{{< publication-list >}}
```

### Configuration

The `publication-list` shortcode is primarily configured via the `publication-list` key in your YAML header, but some options can be passed directly as arguments.

**YAML Configuration:**
```yaml
publication-list:
  bib_file: "assets/bib/my_publications.bib"
  bib_style: "assets/bib/apa-cv.csl"
  author_name: "Smith, J." # Name to highlight
  highlight_author: "bold" # "bold", "italic", "color", or custom Typst
  group_order: ["article", "book", "conference"]
```

**Shortcode Arguments (Override YAML):**

| Argument | Description |
| :--- | :--- |
| `bib_file` | Path to the bibliography file. |
| `bib_style` | Path to the CSL style file. |
| `author_name` | The author name to highlight in the bibliography. |
| `debug` | Set to `"true"` to print debug info in the output. |

### Grouping and Sorting

The shortcode groups publications by type (Journal Article, Conference Paper, etc.) and sorts them by year (descending). You can customize the group labels and order in the YAML configuration.

```yaml
publication-list:
  group_labels:
    article: "Peer-Reviewed Journals"
    conference: "Conference Proceedings"
  group_order: ["article", "conference", "misc"]
```
